text: I'm Nelson Schwartz of the New York
Times we're here in Paris at the
flagship augury store which only opened
at the end of October the opening is
neatly timed to coincide with the
financial downturn around the world and
we're looking at how luxury goods makers
like bolgheri the legendary Italian
jewelry maker are coping the company's
CEO has said that the current
environment is the worst that he seen
since after September 11 and many
companies in this booming sector has
suddenly seen things shift very quickly
you can't really have a broad picture
right now thing's for sure the Japanese
market this is very very difficult the
American market is awful for the rest
you know you know you don't know you
know we have to look for Christmas and
see what's going to happen by day by the
end of the year in mid-november bull
renounced that third-quarter profits
dropped forty-four percent and that
really surprised investors that it was
such a steep drop so people are looking
very closely right now at the fourth
quarter especially sales in the next
month this is the Christmas holiday
shopping season the company generates a
disproportionate share of sales and
profits right now so now the people is I
have money to invest I would invest in
something equality so it's safe with
them the money has more value than
before if you've got money to spend it's
a good time to buy but what we're doing
on certain middle incomes of worker and
so what we're doing is me and my family
if we want something really bad will buy
it but if we don't really need it we're
think twice before we buy it now so it's
affecting us in that way all the luxury
brands Percy covers so many different
segments by now that you know they have
clients of course among the wealthiest
people but also in the
in the middle class so the middle class
will be affected for sure and also the
upper class will be affected from what I
heard from the company sales at the very
high end jewelry we're talking above say
seventy-five thousand dollars as well as
some of the more entry-level items or at
least entry level according to buggery
would be about a thousand dollars those
areas are doing better there's kind of
what they call a polarization in the
market it's the broad middle where sales
are down it's almost closing time in
Paris it's almost seven-thirty at this
store I must say it's pretty quiet I
think we're the only ones here that may
be because of just how expensive many of
the offerings are one pair of earrings I
just saw was about two hundred thousand
as incredible as it may sound they tell
me that some people will come in and
purchase that on the spot but they also
have VIP rooms so if visitors say from
Russia or maybe the Gulf want to shop at
privacy they can and for two hundred
thousand euros that buys privacy the the
doctrine market is affected definitely
it is the the question is to which
extent and that we don't know yet for
the International Herald Tribune and the
New York Times this is nelson Schwartz
in Paris
